VLIB Function Reference

Block Median

Introduction and Use Cases

As a statistical method, median extraction and median filters have can be used in a variety of use cases and applications. Median filters are generally used on signals or images as a non-linear noise reduction technique, but may also be used to extract local median statistics for consideration in other algorithm steps. In general, there is usually a sliding window of a specified shape and size in which the center element is represented by the median value of the neighborhood elements included in the window. This process is repeated as the window slides to for other elements in the vector.

Specification

Function

This function extracts median values from a 2D array of bytes. It uses a rectangular sliding window defined by blockWidth and blockHeight parameters. For each median extraction, the window steps through the 2D array in raster scan fashion, using step sizes defined by stepSizeHorz and stepSizeVert parameters. The number of pMedian outputs is defined by the equation: N = ((imageHeight - blockHeight)/stepSizeVert + 1) * ((imageWidth - blockWidth)/stepSizeHorz + 1) * blockHeight*blockWidth

Inputs


    Parameter          Description
    -------------------------------------------------------------------
    pInput[]           Input image pointer                           (UQ8.0)
    pMedian[]          Output median array pointer                   (UQ8.0)
    pScratch[]         Scratch buffer                                (UQ16.0)
    imageWidth         Width of the image                            (UQ16.0)
    imageHeight        Height of the image                           (UQ16.0)
    imagePitch         Pitch of the input image                      (UQ16.0)
    blockWidth         Width of the blocks                           (UQ16.0)
    blockHeight        Height of the blocks                          (UQ16.0)
    stepSizeHorz       Step Size of the blocks in the X direction    (UQ16.0)
    stepSizeVert       Step Size of the blocks in the Y direction    (UQ16.0)
